114.title: Rhetoric of New Media
114.description: This course examines a range of digital media practices including hypertext, interactive drama, videogames, literary interactive fiction, and socially constructed narratives in multi-user spaces. Through a mixture of readings, discussion, and project work, we will explore the theoretical positions, debates, and design issues arising from these different practices. Topics will include the rhetorical, ludic, theatrical, narrative political, and legal dimensions of digital media.

124.title: Rhetoric of Poetry
124.description: Consideration of the relationship between the texture of poetic discourse largely defined by figures of speech and overall poetic structures.

240.title: Rhetorical Theory and Criticism
240.description: Advanced investigation of the rhetorical dimensions of various modes of discourse. Specific topics to be announced.

109.title: Aesthetics and Rhetoric
109.description: Study of the terms and means by which we make and defend judgments involving the exercise of aesthetic sensitivity or perceptiveness. Consideration of the relationship between aesthetic qualities and aesthetic value. Discussion of aesthetic criticism as the means by which the capacities and salience of works of art are called to our attention and brought into focus. Topics include questions of taste, expression, and affect.

106.title: Rhetoric of Historical Discourse
106.description: A study of how historical knowledge is produced and interpreted. Topics might include narrative and representation, the uses of evidence, forms of historical argumentation, and historical controversies in the public realm.

189.title: Special Topics
189.description: Group instruction and investigation of topics not accommodated in regular course offerings.

10.title: Introduction to Practical Reasoning and Critical Analysis of Argument
10.description: An introduction to practical reasoning and the critical analysis of argument. Topics treated will include: definition, the syllogism, the enthymeme, fallacies, as well as various non-logical appeals. Also, the course will treat in introductory fashion some ancient and modern attempts to relate rhetoric and logic.

H190B.title: Honors Thesis
H190B.description: Independent study under guidance of a faculty director culminating in a written thesis. Required of all rhetoric majors desiring to earn the A.B. degree with honors.

135T.title: Selected Topics in Film
135T.description: A study of a film topic not covered by the other film categories. This course might focus on a particular cinematic "theme," or a nonhistoric and nongeneric category. Examples: Feminist Film Practice, Gay and Lesbian Cinema, Race and Cinematic Representation.

157B.title: Rhetoric of Contemporary Political Theory
157B.description: Study of the textual strategies of important works of 20th century European and American political theory.

375.title: Teaching Rhetoric
375.description: Instruction in teaching argumentative writing and rhetorical analysis.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study
199.description: For special projects that cannot be otherwise accommodated.

R1B.title: The Craft of Writing
R1B.description: Intensive argumentative writing drawn from controversy stimulated through selected readings and class discussion. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

R1B.title: The Craft of Writing
R1B.description: Intensive argumentative writing drawn from controversy stimulated through selected readings and class discussion. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

R1B.title: The Craft of Writing
R1B.description: Intensive argumentative writing drawn from controversy stimulated through selected readings and class discussion. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

24.title: Freshman Seminars
24.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

103A.title: Approaches and Paradigms in the History of Rhetorical Theory
103A.description: A broad consideration of the historical relationships between philosophy, literature, and rhetoric, with special emphasis on selected themes of the classical and medieval periods.

200.title: Classical Rhetorical Theory and Practice
200.description: An introduction to the questions around which classical rhetorical theory and practice are organized. Through analysis of materials drawn principally from the Ancient Greek and Roman periods, possibly including later revivals of classical rhetoric, the course will examine the formation of rhetoric in the West as an intellectual stance from which to practice a range of related fields, including but not limited to philosophy, history, literature, politics, religion, law, science, and the arts.

H190A.title: Honors Thesis
H190A.description: Independent study under guidance of a faculty director culminating in a written thesis. Required of all rhetoric majors desiring to earn the A.B. degree with honors.

H190A.title: Honors Thesis

H190A.title: Honors Thesis
H190A.description: Independent study under guidance of a faculty director culminating in a written thesis. Required of all rhetoric majors desiring to earn the A.B. degree with honors.

117.title: Language, Truth and Dialogue
117.description: Examination of philosophical dialogues from Plato to Heidegger. Focus on the interaction within the dialogue, the participation required of the reader/listener, and the relation of such interaction and participation to thinking, speaking and knowing.

240G.title: Rhetorical Theory and Criticism: Rhetorical Theory
240G.description: Advanced investigation of the rhetorical dimensions of various modes of discourse. Specific topics to be announced.

240G.title: Rhetorical Theory and Criticism: Rhetorical Theory
240G.description: Advanced investigation of the rhetorical dimensions of various modes of discourse. Specific topics to be announced.

240G.title: Rhetorical Theory and Criticism: Rhetorical Theory
240G.description: Advanced investigation of the rhetorical dimensions of various modes of discourse. Specific topics to be announced.

198.title: Supervised Group Study
198.description: Instruction for a small group of students on a topic initiated by those students.

198.title: Supervised Group Study
198.description: Instruction for a small group of students on a topic initiated by those students.

171.title: The Problem of Mass Culture and the Rhetoric of Social Theory
171.description: Study of the textual strategies whereby the masses and mass culture emerge as objects of anxiety, hope, and scrutiny for social theorists of the 19th and 20th centuries.

R1A.title: The Craft of Writing
R1A.description: Rhetorical approach to reading and writing argumentative discourse. Close reading of selected texts; written themes developed from class discussion and analysis of rhetorical strategies. Satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

R1A.title: The Craft of Writing
R1A.description: Rhetorical approach to reading and writing argumentative discourse. Close reading of selected texts; written themes developed from class discussion and analysis of rhetorical strategies. Satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

R1A.title: The Craft of Writing
R1A.description: Rhetorical approach to reading and writing argumentative discourse. Close reading of selected texts; written themes developed from class discussion and analysis of rhetorical strategies. Satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

197.title: Field Studies
197.description: Supervised field work in an off-campus organization or business. Field work should be relevant to themes or topics covered in the undergraduate curriculum studied in the department. Additional meetings with faculty sponsor required. Weekly journals and a final paper also required.

167.title: Advanced Themes in Legal Theory, Philosophy, Argumentation
167.description: Thorough consideration of particular rhetorical themes in the field of legal theory, legal philosophy, and legal argumentation.

130.title: Novel into Film
130.description: Close examination of the adaptation of written fiction to the cinema. Focus on the problems arising from the transformation of five novels, which will be read, into their filmed versions.

152AC.title: Race and Order in the New Republic
152AC.description: This course will explore how the social issue of race in the new American republic shaped the political founding of the United States in 1787. We will investigate perceptions of race at the time of the founding, and try to understand the origins of those perceptions. We will examine how those same perceptions affected the founding and establishment of a new nation and how they have affected our contemporary social and political discourse.

165.title: Rhetoric of Legal Philosophy
165.description: Consideration of basic philosophical issues related to the political and moral foundations of the law.
